reviewText:
Been playing this game on and off since I bought it off-Steam about a year and a half ago, so don't be bothered by Steam saying I've hardly played it.

First of all, this game has, without a doubt, the greatest launch trailer known to mankind: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CnAeHNZAbNs

Second, this is a pretty decent — but also pretty unfair — platformer. Unfair in the sense that, if you're reasonably skilled at platforming, you'll most likely die to randomness (falling eggs, rocks, etc.) way more than anything else. Normally I'd recommend people stay far, far away from games that utilize randomness as a way to increase difficulty, but in this game it works. It works because the randomness fits perfectly in with the game — both thematically and gameplay-wise. And the game is short enough that the random deaths don't become too frustrating. (I realize that that sounded a lot like a backhanded compliment, but I assure you, it isn't meant as such.) It's the kind of game that makes me wish I had friends who were interested in platformers so I could share the experience with them.

Third, the game is hilarious and silly. Stop worrying and learn to love the troof.
voteText: 65 of 73 people (89%) found this review helpful 12 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Why are we here?  What's the purpose? Who or What are we??

In a world where we are constantly busy with and distracted by what's happening, we don't often make it a priority to stop and investigate what is really going on.

Potatoman takes this time, and endures a harrowing platfoming journey to seek out and discover for himself what is the TROOF!

Wisdom and mis-direction is found in all of the characters he encounters. Does anyone actually know the Troof?

While it can be challenging at times, Potatoman Seeks the Troof is rewarding and a lot of fun. There's also a fantastic Soundtrack by Miles Tilmann.

Go forth and Seek the Troof!

reviewText:
20 minutes of serviceable platforming and 10 minutes of vague story are not worth 4 dollars.

There is nothing critically wrong with Potatoman Seeks the Troof, except perhaps that nothing is sufficiently interesting for it to distinguish itself.
You make your way from left to right as is the law in the court of the 2D platformer, and a variety of trial-and-error learned obstacles attempt to impede your progress. These vary from the cheap to the mildly inventive. Nothing too frustrating that you can't get past without throwing continue after continue at it for a few minutes, but also not particularly fun.

It's not the worst way to spend half an hour, but there are plenty of better ways too.

reviewText:
A bad platformer with minimal graphic/sound/controls/options that abuses the old 1HP mechanic to give longevity to a game without depth.

There are 5 short levels and nothing else. 2 Achievements have been added to encourage you to reply this obnoxious game that seems to come out straight from the '80s.

Not even my nostalgia for other times could keep me playing this for longer than 10 minutes.

Avoid at any cost, and save your money.

If you need ratings:

Graphic: 1/10
Sound: 1/10
Gameplay: 5/10
Longevity: 2/10
Overall: 2/10

Avoid at any cost, no matter what.

reviewText:
A fun and humorous little platformer with philosophical overtones.

Rather short -- should take an hour or at most two to complete, for a person totally new to the game; a returning player may take half an hour if they're rusty; and speedruns finish in under ten minutes.

But it turns out this is actually a great size to be able to play through an entire game in a short burst -- perfect for a busy schedule or a short spurt of procrastination.  Not only that, you get to play through an entire game and actually have something to show for it (as a hidden feature which I won't describe here).

Game also features an in-game timer, which reports your time to a leaderboard here on Steam.

Also has one of the best videogame trailers ever.

(Disclosure: I acquired this game as part of The Greenlight Bundle 3.)

reviewText:
Don't let my hours played fool you, this game is absurdly short.

I finished the entire thing with both achievements in 50 minutes, but now I'm letting the game idle in the background to pick up the rest of the card drops. I have to imagine this was some sort of gimmick to push the average played time up, because there's no way you could spend 5 hours playing this game unless you hate yourself.

Graphics are typical of a pixel game, but honestly they're not interesting.

Gameplay is extremely short, and the mechanics are boring. The levels aren't interesting or challenging enough to feel like you've accomplished anything significant if you aren't shooting for the Enlightenment achievement (no continues), and outside of one or two tough spots, the whole thing is pretty easy. The last level was a bit more interesting because there were actually a few physics challenges, but that's not enough to make up for the poor quality of the rest of the game.

Controls feel crude, but managable. There were a few points where I had issues jumping, but it wasn't a huge deal.

In terms of value, this is not worth the full price by any means. I honestly wouldn't recommend it on sale, either. If you happen to pick it up in a bundle, I'd say go ahead and give it a shot - otherwise, don't waste your money. There are better games out there at lower prices. The DLC is just the OST, and there aren't enough tracks in the game to justify buying it unless you really enjoyed them.

Pass on this one.

reviewText:
The title is longer then the game is... My first play through was about 30 minutes with a hell of a lot of dying. Then I tried again for the second achievement (no continues) and managed to complete it in 10 minutes. The only reason most people are spending 3 hours on the game is to get the trading cards. There's pretty much no replayability and I found it was pretty easy after playing it through the first time, however the first time be prepared to die a lot...

Whilst the game is fairly fun though and has a massive learning curve but once you get past it, it get's repetitive. I can only see people who speedrun games seeing the value in this (in fact, seems like the community are geared towards this as well as there being a dedicated in-game speedrun timer).

I don't know how much I paid for it but I assume it was from one of my hundreds of bundles. £2.79 seems a little expensive for a 10 minute game (and there is really not much to it) so I'd only really recommend it if it's in a sale for cheap and you really like it.

reviewText:
Simplistic: Pixeljam games are all very simplistic games that excel at the concept that they are trying to put over. This is the studio at its very best. Potatoman Seeks the Troof is a platform game

It’s short: You can complete the game in 30 minutes and that includes dying… and dying… and dying… a lot!

It’s not fair: Platformer fans demand games where death is always fair or at least fair a significant percentage of the time. Even the greatest platforming players will find themselves dying quite a bit. Usually this is a frustration that beggars belief. Why make a game so dependent upon randomness? Because in rare cases it absolutely works. This is one of those examples. It’s one of the few games where you’d expect nothing less than abject randomness and Pixeljam deliver it in spades.

Odd pacing: I really don’t quite understand the decision making process Pixeljam had in regards to the pacing in this game. You start off with easy as you have come to expect from platform games. However, then you progress to what I would argue is the most difficult part of the game – the dreaded forest levels.  It’s difficult more so because you will die due to the random nature of the game more so than a lack of skill but it is made to feel like a combination of both. I nearly quit the game at this stage because I was raging so hard… But then again perhaps that was their point. Weird pacing that is oddly satisfying once you beat the stage.

Incredible trailer: In complete and utter seriousness this is one of the best trailers I’ve ever seen because of its utter hilarity. What a fantastic way to sell your game.

Potatoman Seeks the Troof is a great little platform game full of randomness and quirkiness that just works.

For reviews similar to this and our daily giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com/

reviewText:
Potato man is a great game with a cool retro art-style and sound track with simple humor...but one main problem prevents me recommending the game.

The Randomness
Potatoman seeks the Troof is just filled with RNG, atop the hard and rage-making elements which can quite easily turn the game from being entertaining...down a downright salt machine.
Normally a hardcore platformer will provide you with some sort of pattern to learn, as obscure as it may be. Potatoman doesn't do this. The game shows this  Randomness heavily from the second area, having the player dodge on a whim where projectiles will land, sometimes even having to die since they won't be able to evade anything.

All in All, I really want to recommend this. Honestly I do...but the insane amount of RNG just makes too hard to play.

reviewText:
Long time ago, in the farm far far away. There is a potato became alive and seek the troof as potatoman. He seeks the troof in the desert, he not find it. He seeks the troof in the deep of the jungle, he found jumping eggs not the troof. He kidnaped by alien and throwing him to the mountain to seeks the troof, he only find falling rocks and bats. Someone says, maybe he can find the troof in the city. But, he became witness of chaos in the city. There is no troof in the city.

Until he meet the creator of the world he live in, and telling him about the troof.

Well, if you want to know what troof is. You must guide potatoman seeks the troof.
For that, I recommend this platforming game to you.

reviewText: Excellent platformer! The developers were very quick in fixing some initial controller problems at launch and as a result the game was infinitely more playable for me. At the time of this review the D-Pad for most controllers are not supported but the developers are working on fixing it. The soundtrack is absolutely amazing and I will be buying the OST on Steam very soon :) It's a memory platformer, meaning that there are parts where you need to memorize patterns to get past but there are also some random elements to the enemies in the game as well which keeps you on your toes. The game is short but awesome from start to finish and the humor is on point.\n\nDefinitely A must play!

reviewText: This game is really trippy and strange. It's a basic 2D platformer with repetitive quick deaths, but it's got a unique style to it, and there is just something compelling about the story. And the environment will react in ways you wouldn't expect, which will both amuse and upset you. Very surreal game that keeps messing with your expectations. If you follow your curiosity to the end of this short journey, your mind will be blown. Baffled. Bemused. Bewildered. Perhaps even befuddled. And it really is quite beautiful. What is the deal with this game? I don't know, but it was an interesting ride, and I feel closer to the troof for it. For troofseekers and potato eaters, I recommend playing through this game at least once. It definitely sticks with you. The gameplay is nothing special, yes, but this is an unforgettable experience.\n\n100th review! Not writing this to claim that or anything, but that's pretty cool. Also, I really, really love the live action trailer.

reviewText:
Why? Why this one? Of all the brilliant games PixelJam has put together, why did they launch a rage-platformer as their initial offering on Steam? Are they trying to troll the world? I don't get it.

Every single game hey've put out on AdultSwim is more innovative and better than this one.

Play Mountain Maniac, a delightfully homicidal mixup of Pachinko meets Rampage.

Play Hipster Kickball, a hilarious sendup of 2000s culture blended with Atari 2600 sports games.

Play Corporate Climber, a game that finally delivers on the brilliant promise of the 1980s freeware 'Avoid the Noid' while incorporating biting corporate satire.

Seriously, play Corporate Climber. It's an insanely twisted, brilliant platformer.

But don't play Potatoman if you've played any of these. It will just make you sad. It's a weird, distressingly mundane version of 'I Wanna Be The Guy'. It's been done to death already. Even the music isn't up to PixelJam's usual standards (although the Launch trailer is terrific).

Why PixelJam, why? You're so much better than this.
voteText: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: I want to recommend this game, but I'm not sure what I played through is worth it? I like what Pixeljam Games does and the idea of Potatoman Seeks The Troof sounds pretty cool. But I kind of feel like it stopped before it really started to pick up. I like this game - it's a solid platform game and I liked the cutscenes at the end, but I just felt like I didn't get enough of it. The developers could play this off as 'life puts you on a downhill curve faster than you think' but I don't think some people would buy that. I think people I would recommend this to would be less forgiving of it than I am.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I purchased this game in the Extra Life Humble Bundle for $1.00 which values the game at less than a quarter. If you look to pay significantly more or less than that amount, this review isn't as relevant.

Summary: Potatoman Seeks the Troof is a lighthearted platformer that was challenging for all of 30 minutes. That's it. There is a bit of story that adds some value to the game but overall it's about the gameplay.

The Good: The platforming is well made and the bits of story are enjoyable and made me laugh.

The Not so Good: This game is really short. You can see I have about 40 minutes in the game and I have zero need to ever go back. There is a togglable speedrunner timer that attempts to add some replayability but I would imagine most people won't be interested.

The Verdict: Seeing how I payed less than a quarter, this game did a lot right in terms of entertainment. As much as I want to demand more from the game, it's hard to justify punishing the it when it's so cheap. Well, it's not that hard.

Score: 7/10   -3 for length.

reviewText:
When I saw this was by the guys who made dino run (and gamma bros) this was an immediate buy.

Don't let the screenshots fool you, this game has an amazing art style that takes reto pixel art to a new, weirder level.  It's more like a retro acid trip than a retro art style.  The music is also nice too.

The game is short, can be finished in 30 min, and is worth playing. The platforming/challenges are kind of a more forgiving I wanna be the guy" style where the rules are always changing on you and the point is to figure those out.  The surreal nature of the art
date: 'story elements' and this mutating gameplay all work together to make a short but cool experiment."

reviewText:
Not sure how much simpler things can get and still remain entertaining, but if the mobile market is any indication of this, then there is still a LOT of creativity left to play around with using the bare minimums of entertainment. Sometimes all you need is a stick, a ball, and an endless road.



Gameplay: 82/100 B-
Potatoman Seeks the Troof is a little game that took me two minutes to download and just a few more to finish, but those were some of the most enjoyable minutes I have had with such an easy game. You have two controls: left, right, and jump. With those at your disposal, you make your way jumping and dodging various obstacles. You will soon learn that this game is not easy at all. Obstacles don't just sit, some jump, some grow, some multiply right into your path, and so on and so forth, it's enough to keep you on your toes...that is until you figure out the patterns for most of them. The aerial obstacles are a bit more difficult to navigate, which actually makes the replayability a little bit better.

Audio: 70/100 C-
The sounds, like the gameplay is simple and basic, reminiscent of the Colecovision and Atari era of gaming, both paying homage and still being a modern game. It's charming, but nothing special.

Visuals: 74/100 C-
8-Bit galore, at first. The game sports the simplest of graphics, having a ton of colors and animations here and there, but things come alive when you die, of all places, as a semi 3D, blue and red hue filters everything and spins away.

Content: 75/100 C
Like I mentioned at the start, this isn't a particularly long game, but it is one you can play at a party over and over, it's simple enough that anyone can get, has enough variety to keep it challenging and definitely something you can share with others. And I'm sure kids will have more fun with this game than they will with Flappy Bird.

Design: 75/100 C
When dealing with the limited movements it really isn't hard to screw up and while they're not perfect, they are solid and do what they need to do. Sometimes there is some detection issues, but then again, that could just be me as well.

Performance: 80/100 B-
Potatoman plays very well on my PC and probably works very well on the mobile platforms as well. It isn't processor heavy at all and doesn't have the common issues higher end games.

Verdict: 76/100 C+
It's charming. It's cute. It's colorful. It's solid. Share it to your friends. Give it to a kid. It'll keep them occupied. It's nothing grand, but not everything needs to be.

reviewText: Potatoman Seeks the Troof is a humorous but tough little platformer worth picking up. Half of the difficulty consists in unexpected curveballs where the game breaks the rules that it's already established. Half consists in a fair number of irregularly timed/unpredictable enemies and obstacles. These might feel unfair to some players, but to me they seemed like a series of jokes that the devs were clearly in on.\n\nI wasn't expecting anything other than a couple of hours of weird fun from this game, but there's some troof in the quips and story if you're inclined to look deeply.

reviewText:
This is a very fun game. I've beaten it a few times and certainly can say that it's not as difficult as people make it out to be. I do recommend this game.

BUT

This game is also one of the most infuriating games I have ever played. The first three levels are incredibly easy and I can pretty consistantly get through them with 0 deaths. But in the fours level, near the end, there is a bit that is nearly impossible at least 50% of the time. I've successfully beaten it only a few times, and I've tried at least a hundred. It's an absolutely ridiculous difficulty spike that needs to be nerfed, because I have literally never been so ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off playing a video game in my entire life.

reviewText:
How does one define Potatoman Seeks the Troof??
First and foremost, this game does NOT have a save, so be warned, if you want to play this, it must be on one go!
This game will make you want to pull your hair out, yes, it's that frustrating! But it's fun to learn the levels and after dying hundreds of times, to finally manage to beat each level. The ending was interesting too (no spoilers).
Pros:
- cute
- nice pixely graphics
- funny characters
- nice ost
- sorta checkpoints
Cons:
- so hard...
- so damn hard
- it made me so frustrated at times
- short (but that's not a bad thing for me)

In the end, I do recommend this game, but only for people who won't give up to find the troof!

reviewText:
You have one clear goal; seek the troof.  You will go to the ends of the earth if you must. The need to find the troof is so prevalent that you won't let anything get in your way.  Don't let the others discourage you on your journey.  They are blinded in ignorance and feel threaten by your ambitious inquiry.  By going against the flow you put your life on the line.  The world is out to get you and it will throw everything it has at you to slow you down.

Potatoman Seeks the Troof is as much an experience as it is a game.  You take on the role of the potatoman on his way to enlightenment.  In an adventure like no other you'll travel through the desert, jungle, city, and beyond.  Everyone along the way will tell you your wasting your time.  They may even throw stuff at you or try to run you over but you will persist.  Many obstacles lay in your way and you'll have to jump over or dodge them if you wish to proceed.  You are bound to be stuck down a couple times but the set backs are small and you'll learn how to navigate very quickly.

The music throughout this experience is wonderful.  The catchy 16-bit inspired tunes will cheer you on as you progress.  Each stage has a unique fun track that are all themed wonderfully to the contents of the level.  The sound-effects are simple and effective fitting in perfectly with the rest of the game.

This is a grand journey but I will note that its not particularly long.  However, its well worth the very reasonable price of admission.  The variety in this adventure is incredible and the story is absurdly amusing.  You are constantly excited to see what crazy thing will happen next.  Its impossible to predict all the wild things that this game will throw at you.  This game will keep you guessing until the very end.  There a very satisfying feeling to completing this trek and I hope you get the chance to experience it for yourself.
